required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Laryngeal Mask Use in Knee-chest Position in Lumbar Surgery in Neurosurgical Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Laryngeal Mask Use in Knee-chest Position in Lumbar Surgery in Neurosurgical Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: Fundacion Clinic per a la Recerca Biomédica

clinical_study.source: Fundacion Clinic per a la Recerca Biomédica

brief_summary.textblock: Spine surgery is the most common procedure in neurosurgical setting. Some centers have chosen the patient self-position to avoid complications such as accidental extubation or loss of the iv line. The aim of our retrospective study is to describe our experience in the laryngeal mask use for airway management in patient submitted to spine surgery in neurosurgery

detailed_description.textblock:
Retrospective analysis of our experience in the last 8 years with the airway management in spine surgery in prone position. A total of 358 cases were reviewed from 2008 to 2013.
Airway management (need for LM repositioning, orotracheal intubation because of failed LM insertion), anticipated difficult airway, and airway complications were registered. Statistics were compared between groups with the t test or the χ test, as appropriate.

primary_outcome.measure: safety in the use of laryngeal mask in knee chest position in spine surgery
primary_outcome.description: Analyse in a 3 years period of time, the incidence of complications in patients submitted to spinal surgery with tracheal intubation versus Laryngeal mask in prone position.

study_pop.textblock: Patients who underwent scheduled spine surgery in prone position

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- elective spinal surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- emergency cases
- complex spine surgery

facility.name: Anesthesia department, Hospital Clínic de Barcelona

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Fundacion Clinic per a la Recerca Biomédica

clinical_study.keyword: laryngeal mask, prone position, spine surgery
